On being met with a refusal , he forced his way into PERSON home , causing her to fall , and hit her over the head several times . CARDINAL . In the course of the subsequent criminal proceedings it emerged that the applicant was a pathological collector of devotional obituary cards for the recently deceased . Whenever possible DATE on the applicant 's own admission , whenever he was not detained under civil or criminal law – the applicant would gatecrash funerals in the GPE area . CARDINAL . Examinations of the applicant 's mental state by CARDINAL psychiatrists and a psychologist showed that the applicant was , at the time of the crime , suffering from a mental impairment . The report of the psychiatrists diagnosed it as “ a paranoid form of schizophrenia in which autistiform characteristics are unusually prominent and ... an obsessive compulsive personality disorder ” . Both the psychiatrists ' report and that of the psychologist considered it very likely that the applicant would reoffend if given the chance . Both reports mentioned the applicant 's lack of awareness of his condition , which made him difficult to treat . They concurred in recommending that the applicant undergo compulsory treatment in a closed setting . In addition , a psychologist attached to a mental hospital where the applicant had been held previously , under ORG ( Wet bijzondere opnemingen in psychiatrische ziekenhuizen ; see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , gave evidence in open court to the effect that the applicant had absconded before and would resist “ all possible forms of interference in his personal life ” if he could .

CARDINAL . The statutory rules governing pre - trial detention are set out in ORG CARDINAL of LAW . An order for pre - trial detention can only be issued against persons suspected of an offence carrying a maximum prison sentence of DATE or more or certain other specific criminal acts ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . A pre - trial detention order issued by ORG remains in force for DATE after the final judgment ( einduitspraak ) at that instance has been given ( LAW ) . The public prosecutor may file , within DATE after DATE first - instance court , a request for the prolongation of the pre - trial detention order by DATE with the appeal court , which will determine that request . Pre - trial detention between a final judgment of a first - instance court against which an appeal has been filed , and the first hearing on that appeal , is limited to a maximum of DATE ( Article QUANTITY of LAW ) . If , however , the total duration of the detention on remand becomes equal to the prison sentence imposed , the highest competent trial court shall lift the remand order ( LAW ) unless – in addition to a prison sentence – a measure entailing deprivation of liberty ( such as , for instance , a ORG order ) has been imposed ( LAW ) . A more detailed overview of the relevant domestic law and practice on pre - trial detention is given in PERSON v. the GPE ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . At the request of the public prosecutor or relatives of the person concerned ( LAW and LAW ) , ORG can DATE after having heard the person concerned ( Article CARDINAL) and after having considered a report by a psychiatrist who has examined the person concerned shortly before ( Article CARDINAL ) DATE issue an interim order for compulsory admission to a mental hospital . This order can only be issued where the judge finds that the person concerned is suffering from a mental disorder which gives rise to danger which can not be averted by the intervention of persons or institutions outside a mental hospital ( LAW ) . An interim order is immediately enforceable ( bij voorraad uitvoerbaar ) and valid for a maximum period of DATE , which period starts to run on DATE the order is given ( Article CARDINAL ) . At the request of the public prosecutor , ORG can prolong the validity of an interim order .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW ( PERSON ) enables courts , when dealing with certain serious crimes , to impose a ORG order on a defendant whose mental faculties were inadequately developed or pathologically disturbed at the time of the commission of the offence . If the safety of others or the general safety of persons or goods so requires , the court may further direct that such a person be confined to a custodial clinic in accordance with Article PERSON of LAW . A ORG order with confinement to a custodial clinic can be imposed in conjunction with a prison sentence if the convicted person 's responsibility was merely diminished at the time of the commission of the offence . In such a situation , the ORG order will take effect after the convicted person has served the prison sentence imposed . A ORG order can not take effect before the judgment concerned has become final ( Article MONEY § CARDINAL of LAW ) . Pending admission to a custodial clinic , the person concerned is not released but held in pre - placement detention .

CARDINAL . A ORG order with confinement to a custodial clinic is not intended to have a punitive effect , but to protect society from any risk posed by the person concerned and enable the latter 's re - socialisation . ORG , of which there were CARDINAL in the GPE at the material time , are top - security institutions as the persons placed there have been found to pose a great danger to society as well as to themselves . The treatment provided in a custodial clinic is geared to individual disorders and personalities . It is aimed at helping persons subject to a ORG order to gain insight into and control over their disorders , to make them aware of their responsibilities and to adjust their behaviour accordingly so that they no longer pose a threat to society .

CARDINAL . According to Article PERSON of LAW , the ORG order is valid for an initial period of DATE which may be prolonged by the court , at the request of the public prosecutor , for a further period of CARDINAL or DATE . The period of placement can not be extended beyond a total of DATE unless the crime committed by the person concerned was a crime of violence committed against , or causing danger to , CARDINAL or more persons , or such further extension is necessary for the protection of other persons ( Article PERSON ) .

CARDINAL NORP The structural capacity shortage that has existed since DATE is not a special circumstance in the above - mentioned sense which would justify ( further ) delay in placing [ the plaintiff ] in a ORG clinic .
